nodes.bodyText: This should probably be 2020.
I would add a brief description: this directory holds the files required for syntax highlighting ddlog programs in Visual Studio Code.
is this necessary?
the file defines various gulp tasks like compile-json. The command gulp compile-json can be used to generate textmate grammer file
no empty lines

Modified code
0b469a5
please fix the indentation here. make sure you don't use tabs.

Modified code
0b469a5

Modified code
0b469a5
This case seems to be covered by the previous one.

Modified code
0b469a5
This seems to cover both with and without exponent.

Modified code
0b469a5
The width of the literal should be part of the literal - similar with the floating point. So you need an (\\d+')? as part of the grammar. This applies to all cases below.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,47 @@
+{
+  "repository": {
+        "constant": {
+            "patterns": [
+                {
+                    "comment": "Floating point literal (without exponent)",
+                    "name": "constant.numeric.float.ddlog",
+                    "match": "\\b(32'f|64'f)?[0-9][0-9_]*\\.[0-9][0-9_]*([eE][+-]?[0-9_]+)?\\b"
+                },
+                {
+                    "comment": "Floating point literal (with exponent)",
+                    "name": "constant.numeric.float.ddlog",
+                    "match": "\\b(32'f|64'f)?[0-9][0-9_]*\\.[0-9][0-9_]*[eE][+-][0-9_]+\\b"
+                }, 
+                {
+                    "comment": "Floating point literal (exponent)",
+                    "name": "constant.numeric.float.ddlog",
+                    "match": "\\b(32'f|64'f)?([0-9][0-9_]*\\.)?[0-9][0-9_]*[eE][+-][0-9_]+\\b"
+                },                                                                        
+                {
+                    "comment": "Integer literal (decimal)",
+                    "name": "constant.numeric.integer.decimal.ddlog",
+                    "match": "\\b([\\d]+|['][s]?[d]\\s*[0-9_]+)\\b"

nodes.bodyText: Is this really necessary? Doesn't \\b take care of spaces too?

Modified code
0b469a5

rule is not a keyword.
Some of these keywords should probably be in the group control.ddlog - e.g., function and match.

Modified code
0b469a5
as does not belong here, it is really a cast operator.
import statement can have as clause
no empty lines

Modified code
0b469a5
There is no need to reply to every comment.
I would imagine that the dot belongs here too, and perhaps :-.
We actually do not have character constants in ddlog. I suspect these should be deleted.
I don't know what this is.

I don't think this rule is correct. An interpolated string should first of all be inside a string. Second, everything starting from the ${ sign is actually highlighted as an expression. So the regex for character below is not the correct one.
So I think that the interpolated string should actually be one of the patterns in string.quoted.double.raw.ddlog
Modified code
this pattern does not have three groups, so I am not sure what this "3" refers to.

Modified code
0b469a5
this pattern has no groups at all, so I don't know what 1 here refers to.
1 refers to "function" pattern in begin

I would actually say that this is part of the function beginning. There are two grammars for function, but we will deprecate the one with =, so let's just focus on the grammar with function f(params) { }.

Modified code
0b469a5

if this is meant to indicate that entity can appear in a declaration, this is not actually true.
If I read this correctly, you are now matching the parameters only. So this should be a parameter list only.
modified code to fix this

This looks incorrect; inside of an attribute you can only have a series of key=value pairs. So the grammar should reflect this. Look at the Rust grammar for attribute here: https://github.com/rust-lang/vscode-rust/blob/c957ad5ff0eee266e9b2506ad3367fcef1f17cab/rust-analyzer/editors/code/rust.tmGrammar.json#L76

I think that the type parameters should be separated using a "begin"/"end" pair. See for example the Rust types from https://github.com/dustypomerleau/rust-syntax/blob/master/syntaxes/rust.tmLanguage.json in the section "types".

Type parameters are separated using begin"/"end pair. The pattern is "entity.name.type.param.ddlog".
This pattern is for type name
why is this under type?
is this the same as above?
This seems to be matched by other regular expressions as well. Why is it needed?
These are variations of variable - parameter variable, local variable
aren't functions already in meta?
This pattern identifies function name
why are all these named "entity.name.function.ddlog"?
These patterns identify function name
I think that the apostrophe should be part of the type variable.

| exists both as a type constructor and as a binary expression. I hope this is used within the right context, but I had the impression that the matching of | as a constructor alternative does not work very well.

after = you have a type_spec in the ddlog grammar, which is not just an identifier as in your description here. Also,
there are no optional spaces in your regex.
is this file generated by some tools? If so it should not be in the repository but in .gitignore.
This should be *.vsix
We do not really maintain change logs anymore, these are maintained by git automatically, so you can probably delete this file.
there are no instructions for loading the extension into vscode.

nodes.bodyText: I believe this file should be deleted.

Based on this file https://github.com/rust-lang/vscode-rust/blob/master/language-configuration.json you can add a few more here, including <>, /* */, and [| |]. You may want to use the notIn condition as well.
This looks wrong, I suspect this section can be entirely removed.

I believe you can combine the previous and this rule into only one using this pattern:
\\b(32'f|64'f)?([0-9][0-9_]*\\.)?[0-9][0-9_]*([eE][+-]?[0-9_]+)?\\b
With this pattern scope of decimal e.g. 1 is  constant.numeric.float.ddlog instead of constant.numeric.integer.decimal.ddlog
I suspect that primary key can have any number of spaces, so the pattern should be primary\\s+key
why is 1 a punctuation?

Why are you listing all these types here? I suggest making a pattern named type_spec, that corresponds to the type_spec production from the ddlog grammar in the section https://github.com/vmware/differential-datalog/blob/master/doc/language_reference/language_reference.md#types. In general, these files should be very similar to the grammar from the language reference document.

This pattern is a match for a argument of a function. The argument is of pattern ([a-z_][a-zA-Z0-9_]). This pattern should exclude types. Hence, ?!.(bigint|bit|bool|signed|double|float|string|Vec|Ref|Set|Map) is added.
this is called "turnstyle"
since you just defined this in the previous pattern, can't you just use that?

I would suggest using a rule that looks more like the rust escaped character https://github.com/rust-lang/vscode-rust/blob/c957ad5ff0eee266e9b2506ad3367fcef1f17cab/rust-analyzer/editors/code/rust.tmGrammar.json#L515
Actually I don't think you can have comments inside an interpolated string.
I also don't think we allow comments inside raw strings
or type, or punctuation, etc.

There are two types of raw strings: the ones starting with [| do not allow interpolation, they look more like the Rust raw strings: https://github.com/rust-lang/vscode-rust/blob/c957ad5ff0eee266e9b2506ad3367fcef1f17cab/rust-analyzer/editors/code/rust.tmGrammar.json#L530
The interpolated raw strings start with $[| and they do allow interpolation

these rules for typedef are too specific. The grammar of typedef is
"typedef" type_name (* unique type name *)
            ["<" typevar_name [("," typevar_name)*] ">"] 
            "=" type_spec (* type definition *)

I suspect you can parallel this definition in your grammar. Having all these base types is too specific, you should probably have a rule for type_spec.
you sould probably call this typedef and not type
all these rules should use type_spec
